discussion.content: Establish a threat intelligence program will appear as ‘Implemented’ in the SP800 assessment: NO - ‘Implemented’ is not an option under ‘Test Status’, Test status has to be set to 'Tested', ‘Implementation status’ has to be set to ‘Implemented’ The SP800 assessment score will increase by 54 points: YES - “27 points for MFA for Admins, 27 points for MFA for non-admins” The Data Protection Baseline score will increase by 9 points: NO - ‘ Test status’ has to be set to 'Tested', ‘Implementation status’ has to be set to ‘Implemented’

NO, YES, NO
Comments by JT19760106: “To clarify, they are talking about two different assessment templates, one is the SP800 and the other is the Data Protection Baseline. The improvement action of "Establish a threat intelligence program" is in both assessments, so if you completed it in one it would get points in both. For Question 1, you would have two options. Under Implementation status you have to set to "Implemented" and then under Testing, you have to set to "Tested". BOTH have to be completed in order to get the points, so "Implemented" isn't an option on the Testing status and the Testing status cannot be set until the "Implementation" is set to "Implemented" reference: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/compliance-score-calculation?view=o365-worldwide#action-types-and-points
NO, YES,NO

NYN. 

Tested the last one and ercluff is right. I didn't get any points until I set it to Implented and then Testing Passed.

NYN
refer to the discussion here https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/microsoft/view/69626-exam-ms-101-topic-3-question-109-discussion/

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft 365 tenant that has Enable Security defaults set to No in Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).
The tenant has two Compliance Manager assessments as shown in the following table.
//IMG//

The SP800 assessment has the improvement actions shown in the following table.
//IMG//

The Data Protection Baseline assessment has the improvement actions shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You perform the following actions:
✑ For the Data Protection Baseline assessment, change the Test status of Establish a threat intelligence program to Implemented.
✑ Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all users.
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

choices.C: Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) sign-ins
choices.A: Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) audit logs

questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You need to identify which users performed the following privileged administration tasks:
✑ Deleted a folder from the second-stage Recycle Bin of Microsoft SharePoint
✑ Opened a mailbox of which the user was not the owner
✑ Reset a user password
What should you use?

comments.content:
Yes, that is correct. Microsoft 365 compliance audit log search D is the answer.

 AAD audit log will only show you who reset password from the given activities in the question but the compliance audit log will give you info on all the given activities.

discussion.content: Answer is D. AAD Audit logs don't contain data on mailbox/sharepoint actions.

Same question as in MS-100 (Question #2 Topic 2 ). 
Correct answer is D.

Selected Answer: A
Only place you can check Password audits. Compliance wont show you anything to do with that. Purview is all about DLP.

comments.content: go to audit logs, nothing about sharepoint and mailbox

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
Came on exam 09-05-2022

Selected Answer: D
Correct answer is D

The M365 Compliance audit log (now found at compliance.microsoft.com) contains everything required in order to ascertain who made the changes specified within the question.

Therefore, the answer here is D - Compliance audit log search.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 tenant.
Company policy requires that all Windows 10 devices meet the following minimum requirements:
✑ Require complex passwords.
✑ Require the encryption of data storage devices.
Have Microsoft Defender Antivirus real-time protection enabled.
//IMG//

You need to prevent devices that do not meet the requirements from accessing resources in the tenant.
Which two components should you create? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
It specifically says, *need to prevent*, if asked for *configure* then C was considered or even E but it talks about prevent means you need CAS and CAS would work on basis on compliance policy here

Selected Answer: BD
You don't "need" E, you may set encryption, complex password and defender via GPO don't assume what is not told. Question is about keep device away if not complaint and thats require just compliance policy and conditional access

Another sneeky Microsoft test question. Practically speaking, you would need B, D, and E. The compliance policy would fix a risk level for a connecting device so that the conditional access policy could determine whether or not to allow that device to access network resources. It would only make logical sense to have a device configuration profile to set the complex passwords, storage device encryption, and Defender anti-virus requirments into action, but Microsoft seems more interested in excluding non-compliant devices than in seeing that devices meet compliance. You judge.
you can do complex password in compliance policy :https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/compliance-policy-create-windows
i would think it is more like B &D
I think its B&E in device restrictions you can manage complex password policy

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 tenant.
You need to ensure that when a document containing a credit card number is added to the tenant, the document is encrypted.
Which policy should you use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
First create the sensitivity label, then apply the label with auto-labeling policy using PCI Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) as a template.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that contains a Microsoft SharePoint Online site named Site1.
You need to automatically label the documents on Site1 that contain credit card numbers.
Which three actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

comments.content:
"One or more sensitivity labels created and published (to at least one user) that you can select for your auto-labeling policies. " stated in article below:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/apply-sensitivity-label-automatically?view=o365-worldwide#prerequisites-for-auto-labeling-policies

If you create a auto-labeling policy, you need to assign it to a label and that label needs to be published. It's step #5 of the Auto-Label Policy workflow.
https://compliance.microsoft.com/informationprotection?viewid=autolabeling

The 12 hours that you mention is running it in simulation mode would be step 4 and since it's not listed correctly, and it's the 4th action, it doesn't apply here.

Also documented here: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/apply-sensitivity-label-automatically?view=o365-worldwide#creating-an-auto-labeling-policy

discussion.content:
No need for publishing the label because you want to auto apply.
- create the label
- create the auto apply policy
- wait 12 (! not 8 or 24) hours and turn on the policy
A auto appy policy has first to run in simulation mode which can take up to 12 hours:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/apply-sensitivity-label-automatically?view=o365-worldwide#learn-about-simulation-mode
still valid, it was in my exam last Feb 5, 2022

Create a sensitive information type
Create a sensitivity label
Create auto labeling policy

I am nearly certain [Removed] is correct. I just tested it. I never needed to publish the label, and he's right that you need to wait for simulation mode to finish for the label to begin auto applying.

So, I can't help but wonder why the other articles posted here say you need to "create and publish" the sensitivity label for the auto-applying policy when you clearly don't. Since, I just tested it and you simply don't.

The question as it is asked is answered 100% by [Removed]. I get the feeling something is missing here.

1. Create a label defining sensitive info type as credit card number
2. Publish the label since you can't use without publishing
3. Auto-Apply the label

The answers listed are correct based on this link. Create label, Auto Labeling policy, Publish 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/purview/how-to-automatically-label-your-content

comments.content:
Yep the article on how to do it in Purview makes this pretty clear. Skipping steps 1 & 2 in the article
Step 3 Create Sensitivity Label , then configure auto labelling
Step 4 Publish Labels & Scan data to auto apply labels which can take 24hrs - no need to turn on.
This looks like the most up to date article. Maybe there is more than one way now?
Sorry the provided answer is wrong from ET but the correct answer is Create Label, Auto Labeling policy, Publish Lables

discussion.content:
1. New sensitivity label (Next steps:
1.1 Publish this label so users can apply it to their content
1.2 Automatically apply the label this label to sensitive content
1. 3Review prerequisites to get the most out of your encryption settings
1.4 Review an Azure Purview tutorial on how to start scanning assets and automatically apply this label)
2 (go with the 1.2 above)
3. At the final stage of new auto-label policy, you can either:
- keep it OFF or
-Run the policy in simulation mode, which can take 12 hours to complete. 

Since it is up to 12 hours, it would be 24 hours wait, for normal work day, you would not wait 12 hours anyway to turn it on, 8 hours could be too short. 

Answer: label > auto-label policy > wait 24 hours and turn on

comments.content:
But you just said it yourself, you need to publish the label first before you can assign an auto label policy?

So surely the order is: (as per the suggested answer)

Create Label
Publish label
Create auto labeling policy

Waiting 24 hours would be step 4 but only 3 actions have been requested in the question.

discussion.content:
Answer is correct. Both articles clearly state the need to publish the labels first.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/apply-sensitivity-label-automatically?view=o365-worldwide#dont-configure-a-parent-label-to-be-applied-automatically-or-recommended
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/apply-sensitivity-label-automatically?view=o365-worldwide#prerequisites-for-auto-labeling-policies
